And We have not sent you, [O Muhammad Ô∑∫], except as a mercy to the worlds.

The Last Prophet‚Äôs mercy was not, in any way, restricted to Muslims. It encompassed all, Muslims and non-Muslims, humans & the Jinn, & even animals & non-living things.

REHMAT ul AALMEEIN Ô∑∫

Some Hadiths on How to Deal With Non-Muslims in Your Life

_Hazart Asma‚Äô bint Abu Bakr As-Siddiq (May Allah be pleased with her) said:
‚ÄúMy mother came to me while she was still a polytheist (ŸÖÿ¥ÿ±⁄©), so I asked the Messenger of Allah, ‚ÄòMy mother, has come to visit me and she is hoping for (my favor). Shall I maintain good relations with her?‚Äô

He (peace and blessings be upon him) replied, ‚ÄòYes, maintain good relations with your mother‚Äô‚Äù
(Al- Bukhari and Muslim)

Is your non-Muslim family hostile? Pray for them
Narrated by Hazart Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him):

At-Tufail ibn `Amr came to the Prophet and said, ‚ÄòThe Daws (tribe) have perished as they disobeyed and refused to accept Islam. So invoke Allah against them.‚Äô

But the Prophet said, ‚ÄòO Allah! Give guidance to the [the tribe of] Daws and bring them [as Muslims]!‚Äô‚Äù_
(Al-Bukhari)

Receiving gifts from non-Muslims
The Prophet (peace and blessings upon him) accepted gifts from non-Muslims too.

Al-Bukhari narrated that a Jewish woman brought him a sheep which was proved later to be poisoned after he ate some of it. The Prophet pardoned her.

However, later on, when Bishr ibn Al-Bara‚Äô, who had also eaten from it, died, the Jewish woman was killed for him.

Visit the sick -Muslim or Non Muslim
Narrated by Anas:

‚ÄúA young Jewish boy used to serve the Prophet and he became sick. So the Prophet went to visit him. He sat near his head and asked him to embrace Islam. The boy looked at his father, who was sitting there. The latter told him to obey the Prophet and the boy embraced Islam.

The Prophet came out saying:

‚ÄúPraise be to Allah Who saved the boy from the Hell-fire‚Äù (Al-Bukhari)

Doing business with non-Muslims? Why not?

The Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) used to do business and enter into dealings with non-Muslims. It was narrated that `Hazart Aammii Sayeda Ayesha ta Siddiqa (may Allah be pleased with her) said:

‚ÄúThe Messenger of Allah bought some food on credit from a Jew, and he gave him a shield of his as collateral (rahn)‚Äù
(Al-Bukhari and Muslim)

Respect for deceased persons

Hazart Jabir ibn Hayyan said:

‚ÄúThe last Prophet and his Companions stood up for the funeral of a Jew until it disappeared‚Äù
(Sunan An-Nasa‚Äôi).

Holy.‚Äù Being holy means we overcome our sins. The teachings of Christ help us to overcome all sins. This

plan. This is the eternal safety of His kingdom. So friend, do not let anyone fool you. Jesus said, ‚ÄúYou must
truly repent and overcome your sins,‚Äù Mark 1:15. If you don‚Äôt, it will be the biggest mistake you ever
made. God through Jesus gave you grace to repent and to change. If you do not accept it, the grace cannot
do anything for you! There is no grace that permits you to disobey God. Do you understand? If God
permits disobedience and sin, then His kingdom will perish, including us. We do have an all-wise God

does not fit there. Remember, there is no sin in Jesus‚Äô faith, and this is the faith we must follow, no one
else. So take sin out of your brain to be able to fit there. There is no sin when we obey God. Sin starts from
disobedience to God, and He does not permit that! So we cannot disobey God. Here is the proof: When
Adam and Eve disobeyed God, He kicked them out of paradise. Do you see that? Do you see any grace
there? Does God change? Religion or no religion, God does not permit disobedience, and He proved it
many times. Get to the Word of God so you can see for yourself. Grace or no grace, God does not permit
sin. Disobedience separates us from God, and sin produces death, even your own death. This is what you
want? God wants to protect us. We must learn His wisdom, not mankind‚Äôs insanity. That‚Äôs why Jesus said
to the devil, ‚ÄúMan shall not live by bread alone, but by every word that proceeds from the mouth of God,‚Äù
Matthew 4:4. Have you ever read that? It says every word that comes from God‚Äôs wisdom, not mine not
yours. So my friend, get to the wisdom of God, this is your life. The Gospel of Christ is the wisdom of God.
Start reading it every day, and do what Jesus tells you to do. He is the only True, Savior for the whole
world and for you. If you obey Jesus totally, then I will see you in heaven for sure, see Matthew 7:21. Jesus
gave a command, ‚ÄúIf you stay in my Word, you will know the truth, and the truth will set you free,‚Äù John
8:32. Jesus wants to help you, personally. Ask Him. He promised here, ‚ÄúIf the Son delivers you, you will be
delivered for sure,‚Äù John 8:36. So what religion is going to deliver you? His name is Jesus Christ, Our
Savior. ‚ÄúLooking unto Jesus the author and finisher of our faith,‚Äù Hebrews 12:2. Amen.

FYI, you HAVE to cycle those goats out to other people..

I was raised with goats as a kid and we didn't do that for a couple generations. We ended up with one goat that was a hermaphrodite. It had both parts. My dad couldn't understand. My mom had to explain to him that he had several generations of inbreeding going on. He was a little tipsy and couldn't get it. He's like ah hell they're just goats not like people. She said "look, your little family tree out there ain't forking, you understand now?" üòÇ

After that, what really convinced him, was this one goat we had. Its body was normal, but the face..

The snout area became shorter than normal, and goats sometimes have a fur pattern. This one had a certain pattern that went around the eyes and gave the impression that it looked like a man. Once my sister pointed it out to him, he got freaked out. The face actually looked like a cross between a person and goat. 90% goat of course, but a few subtle things here and there that you could definitely tell.

EVEN family and friends that would come by would mention it here and there. "damn goat is looking kinda weird man" üòÇ

After he sold some off and did a fair trade, things became normal again. But it is very strange. Not to mention the health. Had to call the veterinarian quite alot..

Eva I enjoyed this so much, I currently live in New York and I am now a mother of 5 children ages 10-22 but at one time I was a little dessert nomad child. I used to caravan with my Great Aunt Marrila, and my Great Uncle Warren and my Great Grandmother. It was the best years of my young life. Eventually they got too old and passed away, luckily I was pretty old then around 12-12 so I was able to fend for myself, but my heart yearns for this life again. It is something that I can not even properly describe for my children my past nomadic life , they have only known the comforts and buzz of America and NYC at that. I thank you truly for this gift of memories.

When I had my first omra to mecca and medina, I was restless when I'm not seeing much greenery of jungle and forest that I grew up surrounded with. Even Mecca and Medina still have some greens, yet this family in this video were totally in the middle sea of sands. I can stand prison since i had experienced it during my previous naughty adolescence, but I can't stand looking at sea of rocks and sand without greenery. Even if I was to be treated like a king in the desert, my mind will break not long after since I can't live without thick greenery and lush jungle. I think I probably have a phobia or some sort. Arabs or anyone who lives in the desert, my hats off to you.

That bread you had is called: Malla bread. It's pronounced in Arabic as: Khubz Malla. It's very tasty because of it's smoky flavor. You can dip it in honey, stew of your choice, cheese or just have it plain with some tea and you'll never have enough with it. It's just a simple dough made of flour, water, 2-3 tbl spn cooking oil and a sprinkle of salt. Dig a small hole on a sandy ground, and set fire with coal. Seeing how they flourish in an environment like that, makes me feel I can live just about anywhere.

@Fra Dee Let me share a different perspective with you. It is actually you who are in a 100x's more danger than I. Living in the city is a virtual, literal prison. You are at the mercy of people and companies over which you have no control whatsoever. People in cities are no longer safe to leave their homes. People are getting shot in Walmart, in schools, at the workplace. It is no wonder people are anxious and experience paranoia on a 24 hour basis. Eventually this shows up in the physical health as well does it not? A body can only sustain so much emotional strain before it begins to break down.

I can store large amounts of water, can a person in the city do that? Can a person in the city store large amounts of food or have the ability to grow more if there should be a shortage of food? I can store petrol and I do. I have a pony and cart, I can get to a lot of places should the petrol run out. If my electricity goes out, I have solar - a frig, a freezer, an evaporative cooler. I have over 20 canopies with 90% shade cloth, so even if I was to have to ration water, I would still have a nice place under my fruit trees, that are under canopies.....to spend my summer days. I have goats, ducks.....they provide enough food along with the fruit and vegetables that I can live a fairly normal life no matter what happens. You might want to read up on air to water production.....we can do that on vast scales here in rural areas? Can people in the city do this......they can not do this even in normal times.....what would happen if there was a long term situation?

I think also you are not familiar with different kinds of desert. We are not Las Vegas - LOL, that is lower desert which has higher temperatures and sparse vegetation. You should see the Higher Desert in spring. You cannot see the ground because it is covered with wild flowers. I keep bees also. I will never be too hot or too cold here even if everything should fail in the system. All of my trees, everything I grow, are in pots and all trees are dwarfed so they take very little water to grow.

You just have become used to the prison and have developed an insensitivity to the danger. And it is not paranoia to use common sense. You should have food, water, tools, a makeshift solar oven, blankets and clothing in your car at all times. That is just smart. I lived in the wilderness for 20 years by myself, you just learn to be smart so that should anything happen, you are prepared.

Here is a link to my blog should you like to further talk. https://expressionsoftheheartfarm.blogspot.com/2019/12/and-here-we-go.html. The Bedouins are not afraid of the desert, they have learned to work with Nature, they are actually safer than you - LOL.

@Elementaldomain sounds pretty good. I'd probably carry 5 gallons of water in my car if I ever lived there, just in case my car breaks down. Do you store water, in case something weird goes down and your grid water supply is cut off? I drove with a lot of water during my drive to Las Vegas, last summer. Paranoia.

It's amazing how you can grow that many fruit/nut trees. I live in the bay area, growing several fruit trees myself. I'd grow more, but out of space in my townhouse yard. Nextdoor neighbors are literally stuck to us. We share the same walls. Never enough parking spaces.
I've resorted to planting in public parks, but occasionally the gardeners chop down my plants. How dare they. I like to grow root vegetables... potatoes, sunchokes, etc. in these public areas.

You have any pics of your property?
I take it back that I wouldn't live in the desert, but I would store so much water.

@Fra Dee About 30 minutes out of Yucca Valley, which is at 3400' above Palm Springs. Water has never been an issue here. It came as a huge surprise when a good deal of Northern California, especially those beautiful scenic areas like the Joaquin Valley, Porterville, etc, ran out of water. But in retrospect it should not have come as a surprise. The farmers up that way acted like they would never run out of water and acted accordingly, growing crops like almonds which is unwise.

I have about 50 fruit and nut trees, and grow hydroponic seasonal crops. The weather here is optimal for growing and it is very rural so not a lot of neighbors, which is nice because I don't have to worry about people growing GMO crops or using deadly pesticides. We get winters with a normal high around 50-60 during the day and summers are usually around 95.

Yes, it was very affordable but is becoming less so. I paid $6,000 for 2-1/2 acres. My taxes are $250 a year. With the temperate weather in the winter and I have sun facing windows in the cabin, I never need supplemental heat. Summers are great too, only having to use evaporative coolers.

We get more water here per user than anyone else in California. We get our water from the same sources as L.A. does but we have fewer people. I see water becoming a big issue for every one else but us. We get quite a bit of snow here in the winter too, we just got 12" last week.

@Elementaldomain where do you get water to farm in the California desert? I too live in Cali, but that's the only area I wouldn't move to. I don't like the lack of naturally occurring water sources for long term occupancy. Acreage in the area is pretty affordable, that's one benefit.

You can.  Its a matter of mind set, of consciousness.  It takes a person who always sees the glass as half full, not half empty.  Only self-starters, self-disciplined people can live this way of life.  I am a single woman farmer living in the High Desert of California. I have electricity, but also solar.  I do not have any big, electricity hogging appliances. I wouldn't live any other way. My life is Happy, Peace-Full and fairly slow moving.  My shower is outside inside a small greenhouse, even on a winter day, its 70 in there. I have time to watch the sunset. I couldn't ask for anything more. The first decision is what can you tolerate, and what can you not? I do not like humidity, or lots of bugs swarming around.....so I choose desert instead of tropical or the South of the U.S.  I do  not like cold, so I do not live in Minnesota.  That is the most important decision, every thing else comes easy.

It is no more challenging than any woman (or man) who lives off grid in the U.S. Or farms. I have days I work 12 hours, I have days I sit under the trees and read all day after the chores are done in the morning.  All in all, our lives are less busy than city people who don't really own anything.  They don't own their house, their car, or all the stuff inside the house. We do. We don't HAVE to work 40-60 hours a week to pay a bank for our house, our car, etc. We have a secure life.......can you say the same?

If its difficult, why live there?

It is no more difficult to live there than anywhere. Everywhere has plus and minuses. Really, all in all, they have a very good life.  They have all their needs and necessities met, what more do they need?  They don't work 60 hours a week or have to work to pay a mortgage. No one is going to kick them out if they can't pay the rent or the mortgage. They have food. Meat, milk. Will you if there is a nature cataclysm...no drinkable water, no food, no electricity? Every geographical region has good weather and bad weather.  I live in the desert.....there are a lot more pluses than minuses.  City people are living lives of fantasy. Any day all you have could be gone.

I can't help but notice how she said she's going into the wild and unknown and far from all the comforts of modern living, without electricity and running water? And right the next minute, she's showing us around the house which is more luxurious than mine, with satellite TV and nicely segregated living quarters. Besides they just drove an hour from the city and reached their wildly secluded destination. I bet I could walk back into the city in just under a day. I was hoping for a more rudimentary and more authentic experience into the unknown? Much respect for the Bedouin family roughing it out in the desert but this was not what I expected. They live like just on the outskirts of town, with many modern amenities, with satellite TV, with state of the art solar panels system, with generators to source water, lots of livestock and land cruisers lying about their more than adequately insulated tent houses? Sign me up for that Bedouin lifestyle?!!

10:48, In Somalia üá∏üá¥ Our nomadic people use the same kind as that and we call it ‚ÄôBur-Xabaal‚Äô means ‚ÄôBurying the Flour‚Äô because it‚Äôs cooked by putting under the hot sand.
They enjoy the life much better than others

For most of us "The people of the cities" we sometimes ask: Why would someone live like this, in the middle of nowhere, when they can actually live much easier life?, little that we know, that they are living the life they know and used to, and they wouldn't trade it for what "we" have.

I find it hard to live in the desert like they do, even though I am an Arab from the gulf. And yes, some tribes in the gulf countries still live like this in 2019, but for the "Outsiders" it is not really possible as we are used to stuff like electricity, internet, video games, the locked doors at night, ...etc.

This video is so amazing, and I thank you Eva for making it. You won me as a subscriber.
Wish you the best, and looking forward to see more of your works.

@6:19 the modern formulation of the Kohel is not the same as the one used by Cleopatra. the following article describes the study that discovered this information while leaving out key portions of the study. the rest has been removed from web access.





By Richard Alleyne, Science Correspondent

3:55PM GMT 08 Jan 2010



Researchers now believe that Egyptians applied the eyeliner 4,000 years ago in order to ward off infections.

Lead salts in the make-up helped to protect against eye disease, the French study claims.

The "smokey eyes" look favoured by ancient Egyptians such as Cleopatra is one of the most enduring in fashion.

But the researchers at the Louvre museum in Paris believe it was originally for medical reasons as much as aesthetics.

Their study, published in the journal Analytical Chemistry, suggests it helped to protect against eye disease.

The key appears to be lead salts contained in the make-up.

At very low levels, salts produce nitric oxide, which boosts the immune system to fight off bacteria which can cause eye infection.

The make-up used by the ancient Egyptians to darken and enhance the eyes sometimes took up to a month to concoct.

In theory, because it contained lead it might actually have posed a risk to health.

But an analysis by scientists led by Philippe Walter showed that at low doses it had a protective effect.

He said: "We knew ancients Greeks and Romans too had noted the make-up had medicinal properties, but wanted to determine exactly how."

The researchers used a tiny electrode, a 10th of the thickness of a human hair, to look at the effect of lead chloride salt synthesised by the Egyptians ‚Äì laurionite ‚Äì on a single cell.

"In stimulating non-specific immunological defences, one may argue that these lead compounds were deliberately manufactured and used in ancient Egyptian formulations to prevent and treat eye illnesses by promoting the action of immune cells," they said.

It is also thought that Galena, the natural mineral form of lead sulphite, was used as eye make up known as kohl and possesses antiseptic and fly-deterrent properties as well as protecting the eyes from intense sun.

Eva: there is no electricity
Also Eva: here is the TV and satellite

@Moon Striker I have an older TV like that, it uses 100W. The propane cylinder is to the right, the orange tank. Those kind of knobs on the stove are propane knobs as they ignite the igniter when they turn. FYI, an electric stove consumers at least 3000W with a 5000W+ surge.....not possible to have an electric stove out there, even with solar. Well, it would take about an acre of solar panels for one big appliance. Residential solar will not run big appliances like stoves and AC. Propane stoves BTW, have their burners quite aways down inside the enclosure - mine is 4 inches.....its a safety precaution so that if for some reason the propane is on too long before the igniter strikes, it will not blow you up. You don't need big flames on a propane stove like a normal residential stove in a city, propane is hotter than natural gas. ¬†

If you will look at the storage shelf where the pots are, you can see that all the bottoms are black - electric stoves do not burn the bottom of a pan like that, only propane or natural gas.

@Elementaldomain Mr. NA edukashion: old TVs consume far more electricity than new ones. Old leds consumed as much as CRTs, 3-4 times more than new ones, ~150w for a small 28''. They also seem to have an electric stove (she was cooking, no flames, no gas cylinder ).  "It is always wise to actually know what you are talking about Dear" lmao :)

@Moon Striker It is always wise to actually know what you are talking about Dear.  First of all, they probably have a 100-200 watt solar setup, which includes batteries that hold a charge when the sun is not shining.  Its an OLD Tv, so it probably doesn't require more than 75 watts or so.  Their frig is most likely a propane frig.  I would imagine they use the TV for practical things like weather and news, not entertainment.  With a small solar setup like that, which isn't expensive, especially there, where solar is much cheaper than the U.S.....they could run the TV 1-2 hours a day.
